page.title: 02Physical Features
page.content: The area is generally a low plateau, rising gently to the west and bisected by a small stream. This stream, Bramfield Brook, joins the larger River Blyth a few metres to the east of the study block and is tidal for some 400 metres, although this is partly controlled by a flood gate. In the great storm of 1953, the sea encroached as far as the bridge at Wenhaston Old Hall. The plateau land on each side of the stream consists of boulder clay with isolated outcrops of sands and gravel. There are numerous ponds on the clay, and many small quarries on the sandlings where sand, gravel and flints have been extracted. There is no building stone in the area, and flint has been an important building material for more than 1000 years.
